column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.2
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Referent|entity|infstat
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=DS : When does a symbol become historical and when is it intrinsically religious ?
#Text=For instance , a community that was once a mission and they have had a large cross on a mountaintop that to them is more historical marker .
#Text=NS : That ’s the question .
#Text=With a lot of legal questions — and since you are a lawyer , or almost a lawyer , right ?
#Text=DS : Well , two years .
#Text=NS : Two-thirds of a lawyer [ Laughs ]
#Text=DS : Almost a slave .
#Text=NS : Oh boy , that was 3/5ths , right ? [ Laughs ]
#Text=DS : Yes , 3/5ths ! [ Laughs ]
#Text=NS : It is what a lawyer calls a mixed question of fact and law , but there is an ultimate legal criterion that is really a factual question .
#Text=That ’s what her question is , and what the Court now asks :
#Text=“ Would a reasonable observer who is familiar with the overall context , history and circumstances , see that as promoting a religious message or not ? ”
#Text=And I do n’t know the answer to that ; it all depends on the particular facts and circumstances .
#Text=The way you describe it , it sounds as if a reasonable observer would not see it as a promotion of religion .
#Text=DS : That ’s always the problem in law : who is that reasonable observer ?
#Text=Someone from the community , someone who has just moved into the community ?
#Text=NS : Exactly !
#Text=You get that in a lot of areas of law , David .
#Text=I think another one that my students in my free speech class were talking about yesterday is obscenity .
#Text=That ’s defined according to contemporary community standards .
#Text=Is it patently offensive ?
#Text=Does it appeal to the prurient interest in sex ?
#Text=Does it have serious value ?
#Text=Reasonable people can disagree about that , and that ’s what our jury system and our legal system are for , and there are some cases where reasonable people will disagree , no doubt about it .

#Text=But I think the principle is right , if it were up to me I ca n’t think of a better way to try to maintain fidelity to all of the values — necessarily there ’s a tension when the government is trying to walk this neutral line .
#Text=It goes on this side and it is supporting religion , which is improper ; it goes to that side and it is oppressing religion , which is improper .

#Text=DS : Going back to when you have debated religious conservatives and they make the charge that what the ACLU is working toward is no religion in schools , and you ca n’t have a prayer group , do you think there is a conscious motivation to misrepresent what you have done and want , or is it a misunderstanding ?
#Text=NS : It depends upon about whom you are speaking .
#Text=For some people it is a definite distortion , because I know that they know better .
#Text=But in some cases it is literally a good faith misunderstanding in part because of the deliberate distortions that they are hearing , including from top government officials .
#Text=Ronald Reagan said in speeches that the Supreme Court has told little children that they may not pray .
#Text=Many people more recently , including [ former ] Congressman Istook , who regularly introduced an amendment to the Constitution to , as he says , “ Restore prayer and religious freedom . ”
#Text=Every couple of years he gives a speech — I read the most recent version — in which he says the Supreme Court has “ removed religion from the public square ! ”
#Text=Surely you ’ve heard that .

#Text=It ’s ironic when you compare our country to Western European countries ; they think religion — and it is literally true — that religion is thriving in the public square here in a way that is off the charts compared to other developed industrialized nations .
#Text=I think that ’s wonderful ! I think religion has been a very positive force in America .

#Text=As with everything , there is a good and a bad ; but certainly on the issues I care about , religion has been a driving force behind civil rights , the abolition of slavery , the death penalty .
#Text=No matter what the religious group is , including the so-called religious right — which in some contexts will attack the ACLU , and in others work very closely with the ACLU .

#Text=Post 9/11 we worked very closely with Phyllis Schlafly ’ s Eagle Forum and the American Family Association , and others , who are very traditional conservatives and very suspicious of federal government power concentrated in the executive branch .
#Text=Very protective of individual privacy .
#Text=They are completely with the ACLU in opposing Real ID and opposing a lot of the post-9/11 dragnet measures .
#Text=And let ’s not forget that the free exercise of religion , they know the ACLU is in their corner and on the professional level we work together , lobbying .

#Text=Years ago , when the Supreme Court gutted the free exercise clause of the First Amendment , I testified in Congress in support of something called the Religious Freedom Restoration Act that every single religious denomination under the sun was on our side .
#Text=The ACLU was the spearhead of that legislation .

#Text=So there ’s a difference between what group ’s professional staff members are doing when it comes to Supreme Court arguments and Congressional testimony versus what their fund raising letters say , or what their radio programs say .
